title: How to make my chapters in a novel longer - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A How can I make my chapters in a novel longer? First, let me ask you to consider this: Do you really need to? Many writers actually try very hard to condense their writing. Many consider stories to be much better if you remove all the unnecessary fluff. That said, I will assume you need to, so here are some things to consider: Do you need to re-think where you have your chapter breaks? Are you making new chapters where you should really be making scene breaks? Are you using scenes and sequels? Scene and sequel - Wikipedia Often writers forget all about sequels, and, often, those are the most important part of the story—the part that shows a character’s real… erm… character… (/lamely moves on to next bullet point) Are you using all five senses in your descriptions? Don’t over do it, of course, but a little extra here and there can go a long ways. Have you given attention to your minor characters? Part of making them more “real” is giving them needs and desires. Some of those can become major subplots to your story. Have you given attention to your settings? There is a balance to be had between white room syndrome and naming the architect who designed every building. (White room syndrome is when you fail to describe settings and readers are forced to envision everything taking place in a “white room” with nebulous surroundings.) Have you given attention to your characters, or is there maybe some “talking head syndrome” going on? Have you given your protagonist a “real life”? That was one of the things that made Spider-Man so popular when that character was created—Peter Parker had to deal with “real” problems while dealing with the main one. In fact, sometimes Aunt May was the main problem and Doc Ock, or whomever, was the side plot. All of these things added up can greatly increase the length of a story. They can also seriously dilute your story if you are not careful, so I sincerely ask you to consider if you really need longer chapters.

First, are you telling, or showing? He made breakfast. Telling. He shuffled to the kitchen, rubbing his palm in an eye, and opened the fridge. Eggs. Sriracha sauce. Wilted celery. He took out the eggs and the sriracha, and set it on the counter. He eyed the celery, then chucked it into the round black bucket that served as a trash can. Coffee. For the love of God, let there be coffee. The fourth cupboard yielded a bag of ground coffee and a French press. It was always an adventure staying at his brother’s place. There was a kettle on the stove. He poured it out, then filled it, eyeballing the volume of the French press. He fished a frying pan out and set it on the stove. Outside the kitchen window two pigeons murmured and fussed and went back and forth on the balcony rail. A snowflake floated past, then another. The kettle began to hum… Ten minutes later, a steaming cup of coffee in one hand and a plate of eggs liberally dosed with sriracha, he sat down on a rickety folding chair at the small kitchen table and ate. Showing. Look at what good writers do, and you may seem a mixture. The crucial thing is: when your reader reads it can he or she see it clearly in mind’s eye? Can you smell it, taste it, hear it, feel it? Once you get that down start throwing problems at your protagonist.

Try digging more deeply into the connections between the characters and find ways to advance the relationships along with advancing the plot. Look for conflict and enhance the dynamics of the scene by showing how the conflicts between the characters produce the outcome of the scene. I would resist the temptation to add a lot of description and detail to pad things out. Explanations may add words but they will slow down the pace, so that's not a good strategy. If you don't find enough in the character relationships, consider adding a new subplot that could produce additional action. Resist anything that makes the chapter longer by slowing down the forward movement.

To think more productively about this question, ask yourself, “Why do my chapters seem too short?” In other words, you feel the lack of something, but you’re not sure what it is. You may be leaving out descriptions, character motivations/reactions, background, mood, or a dozen other things. We go to the movies for nonstop mindless violence, we read books for thoughtful vivid experiences. The best advice I have for writers is to read as much as you can and write as much as you can. Pay attention to what you read, particularly the way writers use pacing, narrative vs. dialog, sentence length/structure, and characterization. Once you’ve learned a trick, practice it.

It is best if you stick to your core story rather than trying to fit in content that might probably stick out like a sore thumb. However, if it is needed, you could go for the following ideas: If it is a story, you could elborate on the back stories of your characters.If it is philosophical, you could add text and concepts from different culturesIf it is technical, you could add some info about various developments in the field, some recent articles or quotes.If it is educational - stick to the syllabus, no need to expand on any chapter.Adding licensed images or illustrations might beautify and increase content lenght as well.Hope this is helpful.

I was correctly advised that one of my chapters was all conversation about how to get a creature who was trapped in a net out of where they were to somewhere else. The folks in the writing group suggested I add more action. Like the creature escaping. My plot couldn’t absorb that, so I let the creature’s lethal tail break free and threaten the passengers on the airboat, cutting one and slicing his neckstrap so his camera hit the deck. A second net provided the temporary solution until the creature would eventually break free from that one, adding both physical and time tension. And the chapter is now longer.

I am amazed to see differing points of view in the answers. Some of them want you to communicate crisply and appreciate that your writing is already concise. Some show you how to elaborate. I’d ask you to walk the middle path. See if your story demands you to elaborate. If it does, check if you have given your characters a more rounded profile. Do they sound like actual humans? If they have flaws, I’d be interested in knowing who do your characters behave the way they do. I’m interested in listening to their story. It could be needless. So, beware. Include only those references/connecting stories/backstories that have impacted the main story or the behavior of the characters within the story.
Why do you want to make your chapters longer? Did someone tell you they have to be a certain length? There is no required length for chapters; they can be any length.

First of all, consider that you could just add more chapters, instead of lengthening the current ones. Nobody said short chapters are evil. If you really want to make them longer…add details. Details about events. Details about emotions and thoughts.

Write as many words as you can,but the chapter need not be long. If someday you take it to a publisher and he asks you to make the novel longer,then you can rewrite with more details. Explain the plot,event, situation more.

It will be a better option to write the entire novel first, then segregate it into chapters. A good book has all chapters of similar length. Also, it is good to end a chapter with some curiosity about what will happen next.

You should have a good balance of showing and telling. Showing could help but don't over do it.Descriptions of important things can be added.An emotion could be explained in a more relatable manner.You can add small conversation that are relevant to the story plot, reveals more about character and could also be a hint. Good luck.
